result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Nicole M Berneking

records.addlTxt: CONDITIONS MODIFIED ON 10/26/2022: If DNA sample has not been taken from the defendant, the Court orders sample to be taken;  and it may be expunged under 165.77(4) Wis. Statutes. Defendant to have no contact with victim A listed in the Criminal Complaint/Victim Identification Key.  Defendant is not to share, reproduce or distribute any personal and/or identifying information about the crime victim(s), except to their attorney.

10:12 AM Defendant Nicole M Berneking in court.  Attorney Anna M Kees in court for Nicole M Berneking.  Attorney Annette E Rauch in court for Nicole M Berneking.  Prosecuting attorney Kristi J Gordon in court for the State of Wisconsin. Attorney Rauch indicates she was retained late yesterday. Attorney Kees would ask to withdrawal as counsel. The Court will grant Attorney Kees' request and allow for her to withdrawal as counsel. Preliminary Hearing requested. Time limits were previously waived.
Preliminary hearing scheduled for November 30, 2022 at 08:15 am.

It may, however, be converted to a prelim status date. The defendant and Attorney Kees may appear via Zoom for that hearing only. Time limits were previously waived."
